Award.AwardTitle: Conference Series for Recent Graduates and Advanced Doctoral Students in Mathematics Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The Center for the Study of Mathematics Curriculum at the University of Missouri is organizing and hosting a series of three week-long conferences for advanced doctoral students and recent doctoral graduates in mathematics education. The conference activities draw upon the summer research workshops organized by most of the Centers for Learning and Teaching, which were funded by the National Science Foundation, and the Project NeXT seminar organized by the Mathematical Association of America for assistant professors in mathematics. The conferences are held in conjunction with the Park City Mathematics Institutes (PCMI) in Park City, UT. The PCMI is organized and managed by the Institute for Advanced Study and each summer hosts research mathematicians, mathematics doctoral students, mathematics undergraduates, and mathematics teachers. The conferences are supported by and would involve students and graduates from all the mathematics CLTs; recent doctoral graduates from other universities are also recurited to participate.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With a grant from NSF, the STaR Program was developed, initiated, and has supported six cohorts (2010-2015) of early career mathematics educators (graduates of doctoral programs in mathematics education working in tenure track positions in U.S. institutions of higher education). In 2013 the Association of Mathematics Teacher Educators (AMTE) Board of Directors agreed to assume sponsorship of the program following NSF funding. This decision will ensure a home for the program beyond the life of the NSF grant.  

The STaR program consists of an intensive 5-day Summer Institute at a remote site where Fellows and Staff can work on areas of mutual interest related to mathematics education teaching and research. Fellows work in several special interest groups, where they discuss their own work and support the developing ideas of others. Fellows regroup at a half-day session held in conjunction with the annual conference of the AMTE. Throughout the year, Fellows communicate with individuals and special interest groups established during the Summer Institute. The work of the special interest groups often extends well beyond the Summer Institute. Professional relationships formed at the Institute are the basis of many networks that thrive in subsequent years. The establishment of these networks early in the career of Fellows is often cited as a primary benefit of the program.

To date, 210 early career mathematics educators have participated in the program as STaR Fellows. These Fellows are graduates of 72 different doctoral institutions (https://goo.gl/qc30qm) and are currently working at 144 institutions of higher education (https://goo.gl/hTu07n) in 42 states.

Feedback from Fellows indicates the value of the program, particularly at the critical stage of their academic career.  Some representative comments include:

"The STaR experience has provided me with the most powerful networking experience I have had so far in my career. Not only was I able to meet other new scholars with whom I will continue to collaborate, I also had the opportunity to interact with experts and leaders in my field who provided advice and mentoring.  The discussions with all have helped me to focus my work and to think about the directions that I want to take my research.  I was able to share grant plans with a leader in the field who offered suggestions and support that I think will add to the strength of the grant proposal. I also have had a lot of interactions with leaders and fellow STaRs that have energized my research agenda."

"This experience was a gift. I needed this opportunity at this exact moment more than I need any other type of mentoring experience. I am walking away with manuscript reviews that I will immediately apply and get a paper turned around this summer, I have a large list of resources that I will apply to my teaching, I have direct advice from very wise mentors about how I should make decisions related to my work, and I have connections with likeminded, serious scholars who will continue this conversation with me for many years to come. Thank you seems so inadequate... I sincerely appreciate this investment in me, and I will do my part to use every thing I've learned in my future thinking."

Since AMTE is now the official home and sponsor of the STaR Program its future is dependent on solicitations to support the program. To date, the AMTE STaR Committee solicitation of donations has resulted in funds that will ensure delivery of the program through 2017. Contributions have come from national organizations, foundations, and individuals.
